you need to retrieve the answer to the question from some external api or external system
maybe you need to call an api to get today's version of the answer you know you're asking what's the
weather for example there's no static answer to that you're going to have to retrieve the answer dynamically and this
capability the lambda hook capability gives us the the mechanism to call a function that you
would provide that knows how to retrieve that answer from the external api or system so what happens is whenever you ask a
question that locates this item matches the question but instead of returning a static answer it's going to call this lambda function aws lambda
function that you specify here and the lambda function can implement whatever business logic you want it to
to retrieve the answer you can also use the lambda mechanism to update
external systems this is how you integrate with your crm system or your student information system your learning
management system whatever whatever sort of back-end information systems you have maybe your trouble ticketing system you
can use this to create a ticket to look up the status of a ticket to update the status of a ticket all of that sort
of thing so this is this is a very important mechanism to integrate q a bought uh with with external systems and to retrieve
dynamic answers this is useful as well when we do personalized responses with q a bot
again i'm not going into demoing that today but it's possible to authenticate users on the lags web ui so
that we know with certain date who the user is because they've authenticated with an identity provider so they have a
secure mechanism for doing that and once we know who the user is then we can connect an external system
and retrieve information personal to that user so you know students for example can ask
what are my grades and i'll bring back their information people can log trouble tickets and we know who they
who the end user was we can pass arguments into the lambda hook as well
those arguments can be static or they can be retrieved from the session these are kind of advanced capabilities
um see illicit response is another feature um so q about what we've talked about
today is is mostly about uh answering users questions but you can also set up cuny block to ask
questions as well and this is where you'd use elicit response so if the bot asks a question we can parse the
response that the user gives us to that question so one example would be we might want to ask someone what their name is
and they might reply and just say their name bob strahan or they might say my name is bobster or
i'm called bob strahan so we need to be able to parse out you know the name uh from the the incoming operand so that
allows us to actually use a nested amazon lexbot to do that as this notion of responsebot hooks
so we can parse the response to a question again the blog post explains a little bit more about how that works and the the answers to the question get
put into session attributes and this allows us to specify the namespace full session and views again all advanced capabilities if you
read the blog post you'll find out more about it document chaining is an interesting figure that allows us to link items
together often this is used in conjunction with illicit response for building decision trees where you can ask a question and
then based on the user's answer to that question you can build in a rule here that determines what's the next question you
want to ask so you can have this kind of guided path of questions that you ask where
each question is based on the answer to the previous previous questions guided navigation is
if you want to build a guided tour where you can take people from that one place to another so it can be used to build tutorials we went from one topic to
another and you can actually build virtual tours where you're linking items together there's a whole separate blog post about
that but doing guided navigation with cunybone and then bot writing is an interesting
new feature that we we just added where um idea here is you may have multiple bots but you want to have one
entry level bot so this allows you to have specialty bots for different departments you can have
a human resources bot or an it bot where those departments maintain the
content of their own bot and then we can create a supervisor bot that sits on top of the mall and use the bot writing
capability to allow the user to switch context and get to the specialty bot that they want sort of like a microservices approach to
to bots where you can have multiple bots but kind of orchestrate it under a single supervisor but
those are some of the the more advanced figures of cuny button
